awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NRT-DESE: Interdisciplinary Research Traineeships in Data-Enabled Science and Engineering of Atomic Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
In many important natural, synthetic and engineered materials, functionality and properties emerge at or below the nanoscale; however, quantifying atomic structure (i.e., local chemistry, bonding, atomic positions, spatial correlations and topology) in three-dimensions, through time and varying length scales, remains a challenge. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to North Carolina State University and North Carolina Central University will develop a new educational paradigm for Data-Enabled Science and Engineering of Atomic Structure (SEAS) to address the demand for a new generation of interdisciplinary, data-driven scientists who can apply advanced statistical methods to atomic-structure data generated from cutting-edge analytical and computational experiments. The research pioneered by these students will ultimately lead to a greater understanding of how the atomic structures of materials govern their physical properties (e.g. electronic, optical, mechanical). The project anticipates training at least forty (40) MS and PhD students over the five-year grant, including twenty (20) funded trainees, from materials science, physics, statistics and applied mathematics. 

With large investments in our national scientific infrastructure at both Federal laboratories and universities, a new and evolving generation of atomically sensitive instruments has opened new opportunities for next-generation science. Parallel to these developments in measurement sciences, great strides have been made in computational materials science, which are providing unprecedented opportunities for predictive materials design. The SEAS effort will develop a new graduate-training model, responding to the emergence and rapid growth of this critical interdisciplinary research at the interface of materials and data science and contributing directly and indirectly to the national Materials Genome Initiative (MGI), a multi-agency initiative spearheaded by the White House that advances the U.S. economy by enabling faster deployment of new materials. The SEAS traineeship program will immerse graduate students in a unique interdisciplinary curricular and research environment in which the trainees will be team-mentored by a diverse group of faculty and external industry and national laboratory scientists. The students will design professional development portfolios that will include laboratory rotations, interdisciplinary research group activities, internships, research training modules, communication training, and leadership-training activities. SEAS will promote and enhance diversity within the traineeship and larger professional community, and an integral part of the traineeship will be a bridge-to-the-PhD program across the partnering institutions aimed at better preparing underrepresented students to succeed in a research-intensive PhD program.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

por.por_cntn:
The Data-Enabled Science and Engineering of Atomic Structure NSF Traineeship was a collaborative project between North Carolina State University (NC State) and North Carolina Central University (NCCU). The goals of the traineeship were to (i) develop a new graduate-training paradigm, (ii) promote and enhance diversity, (iii) produce global pioneers and leaders in interdisciplinary research, and (iv) identify opportunities to institutionalize and disseminate new approaches to interdisciplinary graduate education. This program identified the intersection and application of statistical methods to experimental and computational data in the materials science and engineering, physics, and other related disciplines. The SEAS traineeship produced a new generation of interdisciplinary, data-driven scientists who can apply advanced statistical and mathematical methods to atomic-structure data generated from cutting-edge scattering and imaging experiments and high-throughput atomistic computation.

Intellectual Merit: Research training was nurtured by the implementation of Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs). IRGs encouraged focused discussion on the challenges and opportunities for collaborations within and outside the NRT. The specific research themes included imaging, scattering techniques, computation, and materials informatics. Faculty and trainees presented research and facilitated tutorials on topics such as: Bayesian statistics, crystallography, x-ray diffraction, STEM data quantification, defining informatics in soft materials, and principal component analysis. We also initiated a research seminar series which hosted faculty internal and external to NC State with careers within national laboratories, academia, and industry researchers. Additionally, NRT fellows led teams that developed training modules to introduce new trainees to the NRT. These modules on atomic structure and crystallography, diffraction techniques, microscopy, computational tools, and data science.

The SEAS NRT and the Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI) co-sponsored the Materials and Data Science Hackathon, which brought together graduate students and faculty in materials science and engineering, chemistry, physics, mathematics, and statistics. The Hackathon supported collaborative research project involving students and faculty from NC State, NCCU, West Virginia University, and the State University of New York at Buffalo.

Training and education were facilitated through the establishment of a Materials Informatics Graduate Certificate Program (MIGCP). The MIGC is designed for interdisciplinary graduate education at the intersection of materials science, engineering, and data science with the aim of preparing the next generation of materials engineers given the growing demand for data-science skills and knowledge of artificial intelligence. The certificate also offers online courses, which also makes it attractive to professionals interested in continuing their education. Trainees also engaged in a range of professional development workshops throughout the NRT on topics that supported their research, career development, communication skills, and personal development. The products of the SEAS traineeship include 31 peer-reviewed publications, 3 book chapters, 8 doctoral dissertations.

Broader Impacts: The SEAS program has a total of 37 funded and non-funded trainees comprising of 38% female and 22% URM. Trainees won awards such as travel grants, and best paper/presentation/poster at conferences. Internships were obtained at the National Institute of Materials Science in Japan, Oak Ridge National Lab (ORNL), and Google, Inc. To date, eight trainees have graduated with PhDs in Materials Science and Engineering, Statistics, and Mathematics. Two trainees transitioned to postdoctoral opportunities at UCLA, ORNL, and Carnegie Mellon University via the University of Sydney, Australia. Other trainees have begun careers in industry or academia as follows: TEM Research Specialist (MIT), FTL Principal Systems Engineer (Northrop Grumman), Data Scientist (Google, Inc.), Data Scientist (Citrine Informatics), and Analyst (Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab).

SEAS also aimed to promote and enhance diversity within the traineeship and the larger professional community, particularly through the integral Bridge-to-PhD traineeship component between NCCU and NC State. Students in physical sciences and mathematics Master?s degree programs fulfilled their degree requirements, while participating in SEAS research activities and professional development workshops focused on graduate school preparation. Bridge trainees also participated in lab rotations and coursework at NCSU. This immersive experience allowed Bridge trainees to building relationships with NC State graduate students and faculty, become exposed to the day-to-day life of doctoral students, and learn about the graduate research process. The Bridge program supported seven trainees, including five that were funded on NRT fellowships. Five trainees are enrolled in doctoral programs at NC State (Materials Science & Engineering, Biological & Agricultural Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, and Mathematics), and Howard University (Mathematics); one trainee has been accepted to three biostatistics PhD programs, and another is still matriculating.

More information can be found at mse.ncsu.edu/seas
